DDdo5BQMm42Kxg-lnn7X7w.text: This place does everything it can to make you feel like you're really in a genuine French bistro - red check tablecloths, frogs legs and snails on the menu, pictures of ze Eiffel Tower (which I recognised from Ikea) and charmingly accented staff. Despite this blatant appeal to naff stereotypes, it actually sort of works. OK, I've never been to a restaurant that was this French-looking in actual France, but the food was genuinely great, and affordable, and the waiters were nice, and they didn't make a fuss about us turning up really late on Friday night or ordering tap water (as well as wine, of course!). In many ways, better than an actual French bistro.

tgFagcVbzc_ZM8nQBAoyPQ.text: After book marking Le Petite Auberge months ago, I was finally able to stop in with friends who we're visiting from out of town in December. Our server was friendly, the wine lost was great, and the food was excellent. It's a really charming spot for a date, or a night out with a friend or two.

CaikP4Bm_aKM8KmqpzF1dg.text: One of very few places if any, one can get a roast dinner late on a Sunday evening in a large party in the area it seems. First if all I understand, a tough ask.Over half a dozen of us went for the lamb roast and one, the last well, very well cooked beef of the day respectively, another had steak and shoestring fries and one more the rabbit casserole. We all were singing in unison that for the value it was very agreeable eatings. The Bordeaux was also appreciated by all and the after coffee wasn't bad either. Yes. Very good value. However, not massively keen on the gravy slathered over the plate pre-service no doubt it was  perhaps to mask the late serving of the meat and its potential dryness and we were all severed with half a Yorkshire, odd. But again maybe it was as they'd run out. We all very much enjoyed our evening here and the variety of traditional Gallic offerings suited a large groups' varying desires. I as always can never finish my dinner but please dear catering gods, let me pour my own condiments and give me a whole Yorkshire pudding, or I'll throw the half I have out of my pram well I'd rather go without. I would like to try the a la Carte another time, the non Sunday menu did look very appealing.

GCjjb4VVVEG66ejIdB20Dg.text: A great neighborhood restaurant! It is such a warm and friendly place! I didn't make a reservation and got seated immediately and I really appreciate that. They have a huge menu with all kinds of meat and also good vegetarian options. I had the rib eye steak with fries. It was down to earth and super delicious. Our server was super nice and accommodating which is not something you see everyday in London restaurants. I can't wait to go back and try some other dishes on the menu.

HFsPmN2FcpEZML49obNm9Q.text: Now I know you guys like this place but I think I caught them on an off night. The experience got of to a good start when I called and spoke to a gentleman by the name of (pronounced) Saeed to book my table. He was friendly and accommodating so that was nice. I wanted a quick meal so I skipped strait to the main course and ordered the Toulouse sausages. When they arrived they seemed as though they had been cooked, refrigerated and then re-cooked once more. They had a fried frozen bread texture which I'm pretty confident is not part of their flavour. The mash and Dijon sauce they came with was delicious. I ended with an espresso, it was fine.I think food like this from a restaurant that's open to the public is unacceptable quiet honestly and thats why I've given this restaurant 2 stars, and even then I think i'm being generous. If the service during my meal had been better I would consider giving La Petite Auberge a better score. I'm not sure i'll be returning so there is little chance they'll have the opportunity to change my mind :(Although the prices are fairly low so is the value for money, that's why i've given it a high price rating.

ZzjHI5xqsvSOBA99FIeoPw.text: Another marvellous opportunity to try crepes.  After my sister in law insisted she wanted a crepe, we stumbled upon this cozy, warm town house ambiance french bistro.  It was jammed packed there wasn't anywhere to sit but outside and it was lightly raining.  I am the kind of gal that likes the simple things in life, so for me, their crepes were too overworked , ice cream, pecan, fudge, banana, etc, Even the simple nutella crepe tasted too heavy and not very fresh.  My sis' in law loved them, then again when you are tipsy everything tastes better.  However, my husband and I returned as we'd taken a peek at the menu and decided we couldn't judge until we'd tried their whole selection of food (well, lunch).  This is how this bistro gained two extra stars!  The set menu was £21 (you can choose from four the cheapest being £19-£23)  everything tastes fresh and delicious.  The entrecote Diane left me 150% satisfied, it was a good serving of rib-eye, with mushroom sauce, brandy and shallot, it was tender, it was juicy, if you are a veggie not to worry; try the asparagus crepe topped with cheese gratin.Additionally, you get a glass of wine on the house at lunchtime.  The silver lining on a perfect lunch!

photos.caption: Photo of La Petite Auberge - Islington, London, United Kingdom. at night

BVVOaib54nkckzHVczIAlg.text: Lovely place, the interior takes you out of London and over the channel a bit. Great food, the menu offers plenty of options. The fried Camembert with breadcrumbs was delicious, as was the beouf bourguignon. The roast duck could've been a bit tenderer, but it was enjoyable. Good wines too. Well worth another visit.

YZXK7ZE9INUL7ysqGHXjWg.text: Impressive French Restaurant, they describe their self as a traditional French Bistro and guess what? It does exactly what it says on the tin! They do most of the French classics like snails, frogs legs, coq-au-vin, beef bourguignon, jarret de porc, confit of duck, crepes etc.. Their extensive wine list priced very reasonable. It is decorated as it name 'the little inn' you feel like you are in cosy country side tavern. Generous portion sizes does not leave you hungry.

f4b4nBUFt51flCSHgyY31g.text: Watery French onion soup, overdone muscles... Not entirely convinced this is actually run by French. Plastic table cloths very dated.Great fries, wine by the carafe and very nice staff are the positives

qk3USnBBib_iwUQDd-_spw.text: I LOVE the food on offer, value for money is second to none in Islington. The steak is fantastic, the goat cheese, fried hmmmmm, the deserts, very very nice, the service the atmosphere & location very good indeed. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED, SO good been back SIX times!!!!

YP5Y1OCFNTyb2xt6XSql2w.text: A great local independent restaurant in Angel. Don't be put off thinking French food = flour! Their prawn and vodka starter, steak and mussels are gluten free (but of course always check with the waiter as recipes can change). So it's a great choice for a meal if you have friends with Coeliac Disease or gluten intolerance. Waiting staff are very attentive and happy to confirm if dishes contain gluten. They don't fob you off about which sauces contain flour etc. A BIG plus is that they remember you each time you visit to it's a great way to feel good about supporting small restaurants and ensuring you get to eat out without getting 'glutened'. Great wine list. Oozes French atmosphere so perfect if you can't afford that break to Paris! Whisk your over half to Le Petit Auberge instead! Try and bag a table at the top section of the restaurant as the ones on the ground floor can sometimes feel a little cramped especially when it gets busy. You can easily have two courses and a great bottle of vino all for two people for less than £60. Must Try: the mussels they are amazing! *Tip only try them when there is a R in the month.

sLolFd2gYdr-Zaqn0oqI2Q.text: La Petit Auberge is a North London gem. Its simple, fuss-free ambiance, traditional French charm and impeccable menu are real pulls for me. It's casual, romantic, quirky and charming, and the best of all, it won't dent your bank account either. I recently went there with a party of 12 for a wedding reception and the staff were attentive and friendly, catering  to our every need. We all had starters, mains and copious bottles of wine (we kinda lost count) and our total  bill came in under £300! I couldn't believe it. The portions are really generous and the flavors and ingredients are everything you'd want and expect from french country cooking. If you're hungry, I'd seriously recommend the Sausage & Duck Cassulet special ( be warned: it's massive and not for the faint hearted!) or the Coq A Vin -- one of the best i've ever had. Their wine list is varied and reasonable  -- we had a kick as Pinot Grigio -- and their desserts are decadent. They do a fantastic lunch and dinner special as well where you get 3 courses for £12 (lunch) or  £21 (dinner), but it's quite a bit of food so go hungry!

CuHN8l2M-UHtDVZVoq1CsQ.text: Wow.The food was actually great. I reserve the 5-stars for only a select few, lest I abuse it. I lived in France for a few years, have dated French men and have eventually become a "Chateau-neuf du Pape" snob, but I think this place really had the best food I've had in a long time. Really.The appetiser was amazing. I love it when appetisers are actually appetising! We had frog legs in a creamy sauce that was just as good as what you can get in Lyon. Then the meal was just as good with just the perfect size proportions that are between British and French sizes.The flavors of the meat and fish where both full (and not overcooked!) and delicious. Our service was great. The place was quaint. The price was not bad. I did feel like it was a bit of a touristy setup, but yes, obviously, it's not a real French cottage.One SLIGHT, bad note. The calvados was not well-aged. I believe it was only 5 years old. I mean...this sort of stuff should not be served, especially not to a crowd that is not from Normandy, unless it's well-aged. Grand-père jean michel could probably handle it, but to the untrained palate, it's quite disastrous. Still, it was by far the best place I have eaten so far in London.

HJWrCu8uCBhFG9qw7xxjBg.text: Dining here on a Tuesday night, the place was packed to the rafters. The place is popular, and it's easy to understand why, with a well-priced menu serving french bistro classics (plus vegetarian options) in a relaxed atmosphere. The decor (and some of the menu items: frogs' legs? really?) tends towards the 'Allo 'Allo end of the French-ness spectrum, but the sub-£10 3 course prix fixe lunch menu makes up for it. A la carte ordering won't break the bank either. Not being in a hurry, the service was pleasantly shambolic on my visit, apparently due to new staff and the unexpectedly busy weeknight. I'm sure it'll improve. And watch out for the hothouse microclimate on the upper level - it can feel like you're stuck on the central line up there!

NhroHXLdQ3CAFPUffwywvw.text: This is definitely one of my favourite restaurants in London. I came here with my boyfriend on a Friday night and we were lucky enough to get seats pretty quickly. The place was crowded and there wasn't much space in between us and the next table but, hey, it adds to the charm and character of the place. I had the Camembert Frit to start followed by the Poulet Farci. Two very simple dishes but cooked to perfection topped off with great service with a smile.  Tres bien!

pj9qs2GESbeIaMpwvnjRTA.text: Decent little french resto on Upper St. Friendly staff and good food, at very good prices. I had a steak baguette sandwich with french fries - was very gd.

photos.caption: Photo of La Petite Auberge - Islington, London, United Kingdom

m5m7PNArFCeyJ7WjgGRAfw.text: I must say, despite the extortionate drinks prices, I have enjoyed myself each time I've visited La Petit Augerge in Islington (particularly the last time). La Petit Augerge is a French eatery which services great bangers and mash (french style), duck with potatoes (absolutely delicious) and amazing pancakes (I love mine with ice cream and chocolate sauce!). The interior is cosy and sweet with outdoor seating, wooden decor on the inside and large french style windows. The atmosphere is great, just mind that you don't get carried away with the overflowing wine and receive a shock when the bill comes (but it was worthwhile).

UeIqhbQUTXlOquf7ORhfwg.text: A very charming and cosy French restaurant. Perfect for a tasty romantic dinner.

L2Q41EZCV9efuJmcgqOg7g.text: Amazing little place. Be aware that it can be a tight squeeze on busy weekend evenings and you may feel you are dining with the neighbouring table. But worth the wait french food. Can't wait to go back again and again and again (like my parents do).

SHm96miLrLUroi9EbC91gw.text: A wonderful French bistro located on Upper Street in Angel, La Petite Auberge is a restaurant I'll have to go back to.  I went for the first time yesterday for a late lunch/early dinner with a friend.   I've tried to get in once before but it was too busy and we couldn't get a table.  This time we were lucky and sat ourselves down by the window with a glass of pinot grigio.  I had steamed sea bass which was delicious, a good portion size and efficient service.  I love the cosy, relaxed atmosphere, a traditional, rural French restaurant, with a good, varied menu, although not brilliant for the vegetarians out there.  I'd definitely recommend booking during the weekend, its always packed which is usually a sure sign of a good dining venue.

dNSRrR-ONO4_oVBAuOGM4w.text: I really enjoyed this French restaurant. I am veggie and so am not normally well catered for in French restaurants but this place had a number of excellent choices. I chose the aubergine dish with goats cheese; was delicious. They soldwie by the carafe, which was good because a half litre was perfect for two. They also did a nice selection of desserts.

XRG1pQ0dv_szyt8K-wofyQ.text: Food was nice, service was slow, we we're a big group so I'm not really blaming the team for the slow service, but they could have been a lot more efficient.

bhDYDb0aku1tOY3d5INWbQ.text: This was a very nice surprise. We were walking on Upper Street and we said we haven't had French food in a while.   The food was excellent and the service was great. I highly recommend that when you are in the area enjoy La Petite Auberge.

dHbfwBOefZIGrLjN4L5tow.text: I've been twice now and I really love it here. The staff are all so attentive and sweet and to me, that's what makes the place. The set menu is a great.Great quality food and generous portion sizes with plenty of choice.The deep fried Camembert is delicious, as are the prawns to start. However the winning starter has to be the Mussels. Divine.Highly recommended and I look forward to my next visit!

uNZSHkTAuFfeyr80qRQG6Q.text: Not my favourite French restaurant, but its half decent and here is why. First some minor things which annoyed me a little. Far too cramped, some will say cosy and intimate. I would say not for the couple sitting at the bottom of the stairs, literally. This restaurant can cater for large groups, we were a bunch of 12, so can you imagine us going up and coming down, and plus bathroom visits, brushing pass this poor couple. Not pleasant and kind of feel bad. The next annoying thing was the wine, we keep chasing and chasing for the French Malbec, and when it did come no apology. Wine was average. Argentina 1-0A'last the food. I did enjoyed the food, although I question some of the courses on the menu. It a fairly big menu, with quite a large variety, normally not a good sign. I noticed some of my friends having steak and chips, it looked the most boring unappetising pan fried steak and chips I have seen, no garnish, no finesse. I had the frog legs, the mussels and the lamb shank on mash and dessert healthy pancake, which is just less sweeter and instead of ice cream, its Greek yogurt. I have to say it was quite good, food came out quick and tasted just splendid. All said the venue is nice , with great ambience and cool decor and its located in the heart of Angel. Beside the cramming of tables and chairs, they can cater for large groups, served decent food at reasonable prices and the service beside the wine was on point. I am being mean, it was extremely busy. Bon appetite.

photos.caption: Photo of La Petite Auberge - Islington, London, United Kingdom. Healthy crepe
Photo of La Petite Auberge - Islington, London, United Kingdom. Crepe
Photo of La Petite Auberge - Islington, London, United Kingdom. Lamb shank

ANFvNhnvost7Qo2RsYtaXA.text: Ambience is great. Waitstaff was really attentive and pleasant. Sweet crepes were ok. Salty crepes were disgusting....and I don't use that word lightly. It felt like they were more worried about high turnover than food quality so they rushed plates out of the kitchen.I had the Florentine crepe which had about 4x too much spinach (tasted like the frozen bags of spinach you get at the supermarket and unthaw) that floated in watery creme they didn't take time to reduce and forgot to add seasoning to. Menu said there was an egg in there...no egg in site. I was starving so forced myself to eat half but couldn't finish the rest and felt queasy the rest of the night. My friend had the campaniard crepe and the chicken tasted chewy and old as well as the tomato sauce very watery.The sweet crepes were easy enough and tasted ok, nothing spectacular. The tarte tatin was very average.Advice to owners: Please focus more on the food quality as this is a really cute place and I'd love to come back if it gets better!

LAZm0HgkUbevxk3eGUXSYA.text: Have been here twice now and this is the final verdict.Best: sweet crepes are heavenly! they have a large variety of nuts, fruits, ice cream, and so many sweet toppings! The belgium dark chocolate was to die for.OK: Atmosphere was warm and welcoming. Waiters were all very pleasant and helpful. Mussels and savory crepe were both solid because of the tomato-based sauce, nothing special.Meh: starters & lamb shank were mediocre. well cooked but seriously lacking in taste. They also forgot about our coffee for awhile, my latte tasted like straight milk and the cappuccino was burnt.They no longer make chocolate souffle but its still on the menu.

photos.caption: Photo of La Petite Auberge - Islington, London, United Kingdom. Dessert crepes looking very appetising!

22qfnSAWgXEZT4nanJKJwQ.text: Upper Street is a virtually continuous strip of eating and drinking establishments, making a random choice of one or the other nearly as bad as a Brick Lane curry house pick.With just over an hour to spare before a gig at the nearby Islington Assembly Hall, we plumped for La Petit Auberge on exterior vibe alone, as it looked busy, but not rammed full on a Friday night, with a Parisian bistro aesthetic clearly on show.After we quickly caught the attention of the maitre'd, we were shown to a suitable table in the centre of the ground floor, decorated with the expected chequered tablecloths. Other tables were really quite close to us - it's a bit of a squeeze, requiring the waiters to be swift and sure as they shoot past.The service was very good - the menus and drink choices were out of the way within five minutes, followed by the main dish order - just what we were hoping for.As we waited for our dishes to arrive, the remaining seats in the place were quickly filling up - it's clearly a very popular location.Within 15-20minutes of sitting down, the mains duly arrived and I was delighted with my duck confit. It was a generous dish, well cooked and accompanied by carrot mash and jus. Once we'd finished, the payment was also quickly handled, no doubt incentivised by the growing queue in the bar area. Good value too - two dishes and a carafe of red wine for just over £40.A very satisfying choice.

vK2YHaI6OrJG6Mi0rAPD9g.text: Pretty good French restaurant in the heart of Angel. They were able to accommodate a large group of us, despite being exceptionally busy. Their French fare was spot on, I had an aubergine with cheese gratin which was huge and very filling. The restaurant was packed, reflecting that others were having a similar experience I think. The service was great, catering to our desire to imbibe copious amounts of alcohol. And the price point was quite palatable as well. Will definitely be back, and would not hesitate to take a friend there.

ZEnr9uKAkxi92arJNwOQqQ.text: Great place in Angel done up in a traditional 'French Style' - think red & white chequered table cloths & wooden furniture.  I was there on  a Saturday night, it was busy and had a nice atmosphere but not too loud for good conversation. The food was delicious - I had sausages and mash potato, right sized portion too. Amazing, for 3 of us & a bottle of wine it only came to £52 - definitely a bargain for such good quality food. Overall, definitely recommend for somewhere slightly different to go in angel.

X493pvdJby0WQCGDO4sTHA.text: Food is delicious, crepes are the best, atmosphere - romantic and the service is great.

Qoc4PdsFwcb3UiC36DU5ww.text: Stopped in on a Sunday night last month. I would say it's a good value, but not the greatest food. Maybe I'm overly picky, but I ordered the bread basket to start and it came with cold packets of butter. I only expect to see cold packets of butter on an airplane, and at least on an airplane I can leave it on top of the hot main to melt a little before spreading. The duck confit was a big portion but nothing special. I did, however, enjoy the crepe for dessert!

photos.caption: Photo of La Petite Auberge - Islington, London, United Kingdom. Banoffee crepe

SuLm2JcnpZHyFsMSk1mYag.text: This quickly became one of my favourite restaurants after they patiently catered to a large group of my friends. The menu had something for everyone and the set menu offered a nice variety for a reasonable cost. I have since returned for a friend's special birthday meal, a romantic date night, and a few times on own to work my way through their incredible crêpe menu.The food is rich and tasty; good portions offered for really reasonable prices. The atmosphere is rustic and romantic and the service has always been warm and friendly.

yjxw8jpoiz2MZR1ozMc0nA.text: Lovely little French place & reasonably priced for Angel! I had module frites which were as good as I've had anywhere & their mojitos were excellent too!

eKsVgiyeP5bfCbQ-GbaD5Q.text: Good food and not at rip-off prices. And with staff that do their job just right. Recommended.

iX8zb8bf_kSGETRbrZXrPg.text: I've been coming to this place for about 2-3 yrs. it's just had a total refurbishment after buying the shop next door.Firstly the new restaurant looks awesome, it's kept the old French style decor but it's double the size. They have used the new space for more seating and also added a small cafe area which serves coffees and crepes. Brilliant idea.!The food is lovely, I had mussels to start with a cream and vegetable sauce and rib eye steak with chips for mains. Steak was cooked just wright. My girlfriend had duck in a French style sauce which looked lovely. The menu also consists of many traditional French courses I.e snails, frog legs. The portions are perfect and the service was very quick considering the restaurant was 85% full. The prices are good given the restaurant is in a nice part of islington, North London. £13 for the rib eye steak I will defo be returning.!!!!!

pbcgbIZqDWaRGDe83E-9aA.text: I finally made it to La Petite Auberge for dinner last night after the restaurant had been lingering near the top of my list of Islington restaurants to try. There were a few diners on Monday night but it was by no means crowded, and we were seated right away on the upper level. They offer a £21.95 3-course set menu if you are really hungry, but that was too much for a Monday so we decided to order a la carte instead. My friend and I ordered the fried camembert to share, and some bread to go with it, though I feel like a French restaurant should automatically provide bread for the table. Anyway, I adore baked brie and I thought that the fried camembert would be something similar, but I found it rather disappointing and it tasted more like festival food to me (where they try to fry up anything and everything). They only gave us two slices, served with jelly, and I feel like it would have been better off with a side salad or something to cut through the richness. For a main, I ordered the poulet farci and my friend went with a coq au vin, both served with sides of garlic potatoes. I enjoyed my dish, and the potatoes as well, and it was a solid meal but nothing more. For French cuisine on Upper Street, I would prefer either of the Le Mercury locations, for great food, low prices, and better atmosphere.

0nL-wNKqaC6aNui4kIHN7w.text: Fun place to go for a cosy evening with close friends; if you're relying on the ambiance of the restaurant to carry a date, however, I'd skip it. Our servers were caring (when we left one was actually concerned because I'd eaten so little of my meal - but I'd been sampling everyone else's at the table) and prompt, and the prices very reasonable. All of our portions were generous except for the grilled calamari (4 little pieces) and delicious!We'll definitely revisit.

0kwM8Zu9fSjANJ5DfBPfXw.text: Traditional French cuisine with a wide choice on the menu. The prices were excellent value for the quality of the food, which was delicious and full of flavour. It gets fairly busy and has a pleasant outdoor seating area. Will return!

fdys93ujQYcdqMr-LuG8eQ.text: Just been for a beautiful two course meal here. I had the roasted aubergine and strawberry mousse crepe to end. The service was great, very friendly, and it wasn't too expensive either! Will definitely go back again!

HLaxFXIYq7DGaWgOJvKhIA.text: Lovely French restaurant with Parisian decor. We went on a Monday night and the atmosphere was very relaxed. The value for money is very good and the staff were polite, friendly and helpful. I would particularly recommend the desserts. For me, the main course was not the greatest that I have had but we were all still very satisfied with our dishes and thoroughly enjoyed our visit.
